The roving-window approach (e.g., DeMers, 2004) determines the new value14

for a given cell in a raster map using a mathematical function (mean, mode,15

standard deviation, etc) of the cells values inside a n × n neighbourhood16
(with odd n) centred in the cell of interest (Fig. 1A).17

The search-window technique (Shary et al., 2002) is similar to dividing the map18

into regular tiles (usually square), and calculating the mathematical function19

inside each one. A window of arbitrary size is defined, the function is calculated20

for all the cells inside the window and the resulting value is attributed to the21

window’s geometrical centre (according to its coordinates, not necessarily to22

a cell centre). The search window is shifted by its E-W or N-S extension, in23

a series of rows and columns (Fig. 1B). Then, the calculated values can be24

interpolated, in order to achieve a continuous representation of the variable.25

Given the scale relationships between the size of the roving-window and the26

shape of the studied surface (topography, for instance), extreme local values27

(maxima and minima) may be represented in the resulting map as “plateaus”,28

schematically shown as profiles in figure 2B. Also, when working with roving-29

window analysis, all the cells in the map are taken into account (except for30

those in the edges of the map which doesn’t have a full neighbourhood), so31

there is no risk of “missing” or “shifting” important values, such as local32

maxima and minima, as can happen with search-window analysis, depending33

on the size of the window and its position (Figs. 2C and D).34

2



2 Experiments and Results35

In order to compare the performance of each technique in a regional-scale36

analysis, a SRTM 30PLUS Digital Elevation Model (Becker and Sandwell,37

2007), with 30-second spatial resolution (about 1 km) was used. The roving-38

window approach was performed with native functions available in GRASS-39

GIS (Neteler and Mitasova, 2007; GRASS Development Team, 2008), while40

the search-window method was implemented as a shell script to calculate the41

desired function within each window and then interpolate the resulting values42

with Regularised Splines with Tension (RST – Mitasova and Mitas, 1993;43

Mitasova et al., 2005).44

Two morphometric variables were select in this study, mean slope and local45

relief (or relative relief – Smith, 1935; Ahnert, 1984; Summerfield, 1991), which46

is a measure of the difference between maximum and minimum elevations47

within a neighbourhood. The maps were calculated with roving-windows of48

11x11, 27x27, 55x55 and 109x109 cells and with search-windows of 0?06’00”49

(0.1?), 0?15’00” (0.25?), 0?30’00” (0.5?) and 1?00’00”. The neighbourhood sizes50

are similar for both methods (Table 1).51

Figure 3 shows processing time needed to calculate the mean slope maps with52

both methods, according to window size. In our tests we used a computer with53

an IntelR Core2DuoTM T5300 processor with 1.73GHz and 2.0 Gb RAM.54

The computational cost of the roving-window analysis is proportional to win-55

dow size and, to a lesser degree, to the mathematical function. Smaller win-56

dows are quickly processed while the amount of cells (and time span) will grow57

exponentially with window size. As for the search-window method, the situ-58

3

ation is opposite. With large windows, the operation is repeated fewer times59

and the interpolation is faster, since there are less data points. With small60

windows, the operation has to be repeated many times and the interpolation61

consumes more system resources.62

Summary statistics for all maps are presented in table 2, density plots in figure63

4 and maps of local relief in figure 5. The two approaches yielded consistent sta-64

tistical results, with asymmetrical distributions and peaks at about the same65

values. The maps of mean slope are visually very similar for both methods66

whereas the maps of local relief, although alike, clearly show the “plateau”67

effect discussed before for large roving-windows (Fig. 5 C), as a pattern of68

roughly square areas.69

3 Conclusions70

Despite the differences in implementation and in map patterns (with large win-71

dow sizes), both methods produced similar statistical results. Given the strong72

variation in computational cost and processing time, it is recommended that73

roving-windows should be used with small neighbourhoods and that search-74

windows can be more efficient in regional studies, with large neighbourhoods.75
